msItem.note: Blank endleaves, except for shelfmark information on the pastedown.

support.p:
Western paper
Quarto
Three circles; the upper one crowned and encircling a cross; in the second circle the letters BM; in the third perhaps the letter S -->

supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil in the lower right margin: 1–198. There is an older foliation in ink in the upper right margin of the rectos, which is unreliable (folios 11, 19, 45, 135, and 146 skipped; numbers 78 and 118 not used; two leaves carry the same number 108): 1–194.

bindingDesc.p: Yellowish parchment laced-case binding without boards. Sewn on three supports. Endbands oversewn with hemp cord; endband cores laced through. Gilt edges. Cover extensions and two pairs of alum-tawed ties at foredge. On the foredge one may with difficulty read the binding title ΑΘΑΝΑΣ and a number 3.
The binding is probably of late seventeenth century Spanish origin.
bindingDesc.condition: Water damage to top right corner of the first two quires, especially at where the text is erased in that part; worming of the first and last leaf of the volume. The lower corner of has been ripped diagonally, with loss of text.

history.origin:
Written in the eleventh century in a monastic setting. Stig Yngve Rudberg proposes Constantinopolitan origin (
).
history.acquisition: Came to Uppsala University Library as part of the Sparwenfeldt donation in .

La Ciudad de Dios
Catálogo de los códices griegos desaparecidos de la Real biblioteca de El Escorial
De codicibus Graecis Upsaliensibus olim Escurialensibus
Erytheia

msItem.title: Vita S. Syncleticae
msItem.rubric: Μηνὶ ἰαννουαρίῳ δʹ· τοῦ ἁγίου Ἀθανασίου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Ἀλεξανδρείας εἰς τὸν βίον τῆς ὁσίας καὶ καλλιπαρθένου Θέκλης

msItem.title: Ad Theodorum Lapsum, liber 1
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· πρὸς Θεόδωρον ἀσκητὴν ἐκπεσόντα· πρὸς μετάνοιαν ἐπιστολὴ α´

msItem.title: Ad Theodorum Lapsum, liber 2
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ· πρὸς Θεόδωρον ἀσκητὴν πρὸς μετάνοιαν λόγος β´

msItem.title: Oraculum
msItem.incipit: Ἐρώτησον ἐν ποίᾳ ἡμέρᾳ κατεκλίθη ὁ ἄρρωστος καὶ ψηφίσαι
msItem.explicit: εἰ μέν εἰσιν ἄνωθεν τοῦ σταυροῦ, ζήσεται, εἰ δὲ κάτωθεν εἰσιν τελευτήσει

note.p: A later inserted note which seems to be a prognostic device on sickness, recovery, and death. It incorporates a picture of the cross and below that an attribution to Leo the Wise Leo VI Sapiens Emperor .
A similar text is present in Vaticanus 915, fol. 47v (ante a. 1311).

msItem.title: Hom. 35, Homilia consolatoria
Homilia consolatoria ad aegrotum
msItem.rubric: Λόγος ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Βασιλείου
msItem.note: The authorship of this text has been disputed, another suggestion being Basilius Caesariensis , or Pseudo-Basil.

U (

msItem.title: Ep. 2, Ad Gregorium Nazianzenum Gregorius Nazianzenus
Epistula magna (excerptum)
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ παραίνεσις πρὸς τοὺς εἰσαγομένους ἐν κοινοβίῳ· καὶ πρὸς τοὺς ἡγουμένους τῆς ἀδελφότητος
msItem.incipit: Πρῶτον πάντων ὁ τῷ σκοπῷ τῆς εὐσεβείας

note.p: The τοῦ αὐτοῦ in the manuscript title refers to Basilius Caesariensis ; cf. CPG 2951, where it is described from this ms as unpublished; Pinakes (Oratio Exhortatoria).

The excerpt corresponds to the following passage in Werner Jaeger ’s edition:
Werner Jaeger
http://viaf.org/viaf/46762703
Two Rediscovered Works of Ancient Christian Literature: Gregory of Nyssa and Macarius Leiden
.

bibl.title: Two Rediscovered Works of Ancient Christian Literature: Gregory of Nyssa and Macarius

msItem.title: Sermo 12, De Ascetica disciplina
msItem.incipit: Δεῖ τὸν νέον ἀσκεῖν τὸν ἀκτήμονα βίον

msItem.title: Ep. 173, Ad Theodoram
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ πρὸς κανονικήν· περὶ βίου κανονικοῦ

msItem.title: Ep. 150, Ad Amphilochium
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ Ἀμφιλοχίῳ ὡς παρὰ Ἡρακλίου· περὶ ἀσκήσεως καὶ βίου μοναχοῦ

msItem.title: Ep. 41, Ad Iulianum
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ πρὸς Ἰουλιανὸν τὸν παραβάτην

msItem.title: Confessio Fidei
msItem.incipit: Πιστεύω εἰς ἕνα Θεὸν πατέρα παντοκράτορα
msItem.explicit: τῶν κατὰ τὴν προκειμένην ὁμολογίαν πιστευόντων καὶ φοβουμένων τὸν Θεὸν ἀμήν
msItem.note: Although the incipit is similar to Basil of Caesarea, Ep. 125 (ii), CPG 2900 (=PG 32 col. 548), the text is not the same and remains so far unidentified; cf. also Eusebius, De ecclesiastica theologia, book 1, ch. 8. sect. 2, l. 11.

msItem.title: Ep. ad Basilium (Ep. 40 inter Basilii epistulas)
msItem.rubric: Ἐπιστολὴ Ἰουλιάνου τοῦ παραβάτου πεμφθεῖσα πρὸς τὸν Βασίλειον
msItem.incipit: Τὸ ἐμφυτόν μου ἐκ παιδόθεν γαληνὸν

note.p: This text is written on an inserted leaf, probably as a companion piece to Basil’s letter to the Emperor on , above. The verso page, , is blank.

msItem.title: Ep. 115, Ad Simpliciam Haereticam
msItem.rubric: Τοῦ αὐτοῦ Σιμπλικίᾳ αἱρετικῇ· καὶ κατ’ εὐνούχων

msItem.title: Excerptum medicum
msItem.incipit: Ὥσπερ ὑπὸ πιασμοῦ δεῖ τε ἡ ἐυεκτοῦσα σὰρξ
msItem.explicit: θατέρου γὰρ λείποντος, δυσχερὴς ἡ τελείωσις
msItem.note: The microtext is a secondary but contemporary addition in the blank part of the page.

msItem.title: Ascetica quaedam
msItem.rubric: Περὶ τοῦ γέροντος τοῦ πρὸς τῇ ἐξόδῳ αὐτοῦ ἀπολέσθαι κινδυνεύσαντος
msItem.incipit: Ποτὲ τίς γέρων ἔμενεν μετὰ εὐλαβοὺς ἀδελφοῦ μοναχοῦ ἱκανὰ ἔτη προβεβηκὸς
msItem.explicit: ἐγένετο μετὰ ψαλμῶν καὶ εὐχῶν κατὰ τὸ ἔθος ἡ τάφη τοῦ γέροντος

note.p: This text is unidentified so far.

On a later inserted note on coins and their values: Ἰστέον ὅτι τὰ λεπτὰ καλοῦνται ἀσσάρια, ἤγουν τὰ νουμμία ἑξήκοντα ἀσσαρίων ὑπήρχε τὸ δεινάριον· ἕκατον δειναρίων ὑπήρχε ὁ ἄργυρος καὶ πέπραται ὁ κύριος δὲ εἰς λʹ ἀργυρίων, ἅτινα συνάγονται ͵Γ δεινάρια, γινόμενα χρυσοῦ δὲ νουμμία ρʹ. For a similar passage, cf. Nicolaus Catascepenus , Vita sancti Cyrilli Phileotae 37, 7. Above the note perhaps a name (difficult to read) and the word φιλοσόφου.

collation.p: After there are two stubs of fine parchment. is an independent leaf, a makeshift insertion tacked in with the help of a couple of knots. The last two leaves in the volume are pasted to the preceding quaternion.
collation.signatures: Generally in the upper right margin of first recto and the lower right margin of last verso, beginning with βʹ on and ending with κδʹ on . Some of the signatures, especially on recto pages, have been trimmed out. The signatures are marked by a short horizontal stroke above the letter, and appear to be written in the same colour as the ink of the text.

bibl.title: Répertoire de réglures dans les manuscrits grecs sur parchemin: base de données
Sautel

handDesc.handNote: This expert and consistent hand writes a Perlschrift of small modules and fast ductus, typical of the monastic production of the middle of the eleventh century. The oblique strokes of Kappas, Chis and Lambdas produce an angular effect and impress a movement to the right, though the letters are not themselves visibly slanted. The vertical stroke of Kappa has a small hook when the letter is enlarged in the margin. Although the writing is relaxed, no excesses are present.
A later addition on a separately inserted leaf. The hand is, according to Stig Yngve Rudberg , datable to the fourteenth cetury.

decoDesc.p: Rubrics are written in brown ink but written over with red ink, forming a kind of characteristic halo (similar to yellow spalmature in Southern Italian mss). Subtitles (or other division headings) are numerous. Simple dividers, such as a dot-filled line, sometimes combined with crosses, further mark the text divisions. Initials are simple enlarged majuscules, sometimes in red.
